error.regex: No routes matched location|useRoutes.*no matches|No route matches|Matched leaf route at location.*does not have an element

verdict.summary: React Router v6 cannot find a matching route for the current URL. Common causes: missing catch-all route, incorrect path patterns, basename mismatch, or nested routes not using relative paths.

dead_ends.action: Redirect all unmatched routes to the home page
dead_ends.why_fails: Hides navigation bugs and broken links. Users land on the wrong page silently with no indication that their intended URL was invalid.

dead_ends.action: Use exact prop on Route components (React Router v5 pattern)
dead_ends.why_fails: React Router v6 removed the exact prop; all routes match exactly by default. Using exact has no effect and the real issue is elsewhere.
dead_ends.condition: When migrating from React Router v5 to v6

workarounds.action: Add a catch-all route with path="*" that renders a 404 page
workarounds.how: <Routes><Route path="/" element={<Home />} /><Route path="/about" element={<About />} /><Route path="*" element={<NotFound />} /></Routes>

workarounds.action: Ensure basename is set correctly on BrowserRouter when app is hosted at a subpath
workarounds.condition: When the app is deployed at a subpath like /my-app/

workarounds.action: Use relative paths in nested routes instead of absolute paths
workarounds.how: In nested routes, use path="settings" not path="/dashboard/settings". The parent route path is prepended automatically.

leads_to.condition: When the router error is not caught and propagates up to crash the app

preceded_by.condition: When a lazy-loaded route component fails to load and the route match fails

frequently_confused_with.distinction: router-no-match is a routing configuration error about unmatched URL paths, while context-provider-missing is about missing React Context providers (though both can produce 'cannot read properties of undefined' errors)
